question:
The following sentence has been divided into four segments. Identify the segment that contains an error.
Mr. Abhilash and his family / have received / no informations / about the incident.

(SSC CGL 2024 T-1 : 09-Sep Shift 1)
option_4: Mr. Abhilash and his family
solution:
Correct Answer: no informations

Explanation: The word "information" is an uncountable noun and does not take a plural form. The correct phrase should be "no information."

question:
Parts of the following sentence have been given as options. Select the option that contains an error.
Every students in the hostel decided to travel to Delhi to witness the Republic Day parade.

(SSC CGL 2024 T-1 : 09-Sep Shift 2)
option_1: Every students in the hostel
option_3: decided to travel to Delhi
solution:
Correct Answer:Every students in the hostel

Explanation: The phrase "Every students" is incorrect because "every" is a singular determiner and should be followed by a singular noun.

question:
Identify the error in the following sentence.
Ourselves should not boast of one‚Äôs knowledge.

(SSC CGL 2024 T-1 : 23-Sep Shift 1)
solution:
Correct Answer: Ourselves

Explanation:
The error is in the word "Ourselves." The reflexive pronoun "ourselves" is incorrectly used here. In the sentence, the subject should be "We," not "Ourselves." Reflexive pronouns like "ourselves" are used when the subject and object are the same person, but here, "We" is the subject, and "one‚Äôs knowledge" is the object, so the correct pronoun to use would be "We."

question:
Parts of the following sentence have been given as options. Select the option that contains an error.
Himalayas include the highest mountains in the world and feed almost 20% of the earth‚Äôs population.

(SSC CPO 2024 T-1 : 28 June Shift-3)
option_2: almost 20% of the earth‚Äôs population.
solution:
The sentence contains an error in the phrase: "Himalayas include the".

The error is that the word "Himalayas" is a plural noun, and it should be followed by "are" instead of "include". The correct construction should be "The Himalayas are the highest mountains in the world..."

So, the correct answer is: "Himalayas include the".

question:
Select the most appropriate option that rectifies the error(s) in the following sentence.
One must do his/her duty proparly.

(SSC CPO 2024 T-1 : 27 June Shift-2)
option_1: One must do one's duty properly.
option_2: One must do one‚Äôs duti proprly.
option_3: One must do once duty proparly.
option_4: One must do ones duty properly.
solution:
The most appropriate option is:
"One must do one's duty properly."

Explanation:

  • "One" is a singular pronoun, so the possessive form should be "one's" instead of "his/her" to maintain grammatical consistency.

  • "Properly" is the correct spelling, replacing the misspelled "proparly."

  • The corrected sentence uses correct grammar, spelling, and pronoun agreement.

Corrected Sentence:

"One must do one's duty properly."

question:
The following sentence has been split into four segments. Identify the segment that contains a grammatical error.
Most of the committee / are here to / decide the fate of / this ancient building.

(SSC CPO 2024 T-1 : 29 June Shift-1)
solution:
The segment with the grammatical error is "are here to."

The correct form should be "is here to" because "committee" is a collective noun, which is typically treated as singular. Thus, the sentence should read: "Most of the committee is here to decide the fate of this ancient building."

question:
The following sentence has been split into four segments. Identify the segment that contains an error.
One of the great rivers / of China, a Hwang Ho, / originates from the / eastern face of Tibet.

(SSC Steno 2024 T-1 : 10 Dec Shift-2)
option_1: One of the great rivers
option_3: of China, a Hwang Ho,
solution:
Correct Answer: - "Of China, a Hwang Ho,".

Explanation: The phrase "a Hwang Ho" is incorrect because "Hwang Ho" (also known as the Yellow River) is a proper noun and should not be preceded by "a." The correct phrasing should be: "of China, the Hwang Ho,".

The sentence should read:
"One of the great rivers of China, the Hwang Ho, originates from the eastern face of Tibet."

question:
The following sentence has been split into four segments. Identify the segment that contains a grammatical error.
Though the / global financial crisis, / China's economy continues / to grow at an impressive rate.

(SSC Steno 2024 T-1 : 11 Dec Shift-2)
option_1: to grow at an impressive rate.
solution:
Correct Answer: - "Though the".

Explanation:

The phrase "Though the" is incomplete and needs to be followed by a noun or noun phrase to form a correct structure. It should be "Though the global financial crisis" or simply "Despite the global financial crisis."

question:
The following sentence has been divided into parts. One of them may contain an error. Select the part that contains the error from the given options. If you don‚Äôt find any error, mark ‚ÄòNo error‚Äô as your answer.
Raghu did not get the job / because he did not have / experience enough for the post.

(SSC Steno 2024 T-1 : 11 Dec Shift-2)
option_1: because he did not have
option_3: Raghu did not get the job
option_4: experience enough for the post
solution:
Correct Answer: -"experience enough for the post"

.

Explanation:

The correct phrasing should be "enough experience for the post". In English, the adjective "enough" comes before the noun it modifies.

The corrected sentence is: "Raghu did not get the job because he did not have enough experience for the post."

question:
Parts of the following sentence have been underlined and given as options. Select the option that contains an error.
HÃ≤aÃ≤sÃ≤ Gita aÃ≤nÃ≤yÃ≤ previous knowledge of wÃ≤oÃ≤rÃ≤kÃ≤ wÃ≤iÃ≤tÃ≤hÃ≤ junior colleagues?

(SSC CGL 2022 T-1 : 1 Dec Shift-4)
solution:
Correct Answer:work

Explanation:
The sentence is:
"Has Gita any previous knowledge of work with junior colleagues?"

The phrase "knowledge of work" is grammatically awkward here. In standard usage, we say:

  • "knowledge of working with..." (using the gerund form "working")
    or

  • "experience of working with..." if we're talking about practical experience.

So the corrected sentence should be:
"Has Gita any previous knowledge of working with junior colleagues?"

Let‚Äôs evaluate the options:

  • Has ‚úÖ ‚Äì grammatically acceptable in formal British English (though "Does Gita have..." is more common in modern usage).

  • Any ‚úÖ ‚Äì correct usage.

  • with ‚úÖ ‚Äì correct preposition to pair with "working."

  • Work ‚ùå ‚Äì incorrect form; should be "working" in this context.

‚úÖ Correct answer: work.

question:
The following sentence has been split into four segments. Identify the segment that contains a grammatical error.
My house / is more / spacious than / my sister.

(SSC CGL 2021 T-1 : 12 Apr S1 (9 to 10 AM))
solution:
Explanation:

The sentence:

My house / is more / spacious than / my sister.

has a comparison error ‚Äî specifically a comparison of unlike things.

üß† Error Type:

Illogical comparison
You're comparing:

  • My house üîÅ My sister

But these two are not comparable.
We should compare:

  • My house üîÅ my sister's house (or my sister‚Äôs)

‚úÖ Correct sentence:

My house is more spacious than my sister‚Äôs.

‚úÖ "sister's" (possessive form) refers to her house and makes the comparison logical.

‚ö†Ô∏è Why the other segments are correct:

  • "My house" ‚Äì ‚úÖ Correct subject.

  • "is more" ‚Äì ‚úÖ Proper comparative structure.

  • "spacious than" ‚Äì ‚úÖ Correct comparative form.

‚úÖ Final Answer:

my sister (‚ùå should be ‚Äúmy sister‚Äôs‚Äù)

question:
The following sentence has been divided into parts. One of them contains an error. Select the part that contains the error from the given options.
The Principal requested / the teacher‚Äôs / to monitor / and take care of the small children.

(SSC CGL 2020 T-1 : 16 August Shift 1 (9 to 10 AM))
option_3: and take care of the small children
solution:
Correct Answer: the teacher‚Äôs

Solution:
The error is in "the teacher‚Äôs" ‚Äì the apostrophe is wrongly used.
Here, we are referring to multiple teachers (plural), not possession.
So it should be "the teachers" (plural noun), not "the teacher‚Äôs" (possessive).

Correct sentence:
The Principal requested the teachers to monitor and take care of the small children.

question:
The following sentence has been split into four segments. Identify the segment that contains a grammatical error.
There have been / three breaks-in / in our society / this month.

(SSC CGL 2021 T-1 : 18 Apr S2 (12_30 to 1_30 PM))
solution:
Explanation:

  • The phrase "breaks-in" is incorrect.

  • The correct plural form of "break-in" is "break-ins" ‚Äî the hyphen comes after the plural "s", not before it.

‚úÖ Correct Form:

There have been three break-ins in our society this month.

üõ†Ô∏è Part of Speech with Error:

  • Noun (compound noun) ‚Äì Incorrect pluralization of the compound noun "break-in".

‚ùå Wrong: breaks-in

‚úÖ Right: break-ins

‚úÖ Final Answer: three breaks-in

question:
The following sentence has been divided into parts. One of them contains an error. Select the part that contains the error from the given options.
The Taj Mahal / is one of / the most beautiful / creation in the world.

(SSC CGL 2021 T-1 : 19 Apr S1 (9 to 10 AM))
solution:
Explanation:

Correct Answer: creation in the world

üîç What‚Äôs the grammatical issue?

  • Error Type: Number agreement (singular/plural noun)

  • Part of speech affected: Noun (creation)

üìò Rule: "One of the + superlative adjective + plural noun"

When using the phrase ‚Äúone of the most‚Ä¶‚Äù, it must be followed by a plural noun, because "one of" implies a choice from many.

‚ùå "creation" ‚Üí singular ‚ùå

‚úÖ It should be: ‚Äúcreations‚Äù (plural)

‚úÖ Correct version of the sentence:

üëâ ‚ÄúThe Taj Mahal is one of the most beautiful creations in the world.‚Äù

‚úÖ Other parts:

  • The Taj Mahal ‚Äì ‚úÖ Correct subject

  • Is one of ‚Äì ‚úÖ Correct phrase introducing selection

  • The most beautiful ‚Äì ‚úÖ Correct superlative phrase

üü¢ So, the segment with the grammatical error is: ‚Äúcreation in the world‚Äù,because ‚Äúcreation‚Äù should be ‚Äúcreations‚Äù to match the structure after "one of the most..."

question:
The following sentence has been split into four segments. Identify the segment that contains a grammatical error.
We bought / two dozens / mangoes from / the market.

(SSC CGL 2021 T-1 : 20 Apr S3 (4 to 5 PM))
solution:
Explanation:

Segment A: We bought

  • ‚úÖ Correct

  • Simple past tense of "buy" used properly

  • Subject‚Äìverb agreement is fine

  • No error here

üî∏ Segment B: two dozens

  • ‚ùå Incorrect

‚ö†Ô∏è Explanation of the error:

üîπ Rule involved:

When a number is used before countable units like dozen, hundred, thousand, etc., these words remain in the singular form.

So we say:
‚úÖ two dozen mangoes ‚ùå two dozens mangoes

Dozen is acting as a quantifier here, not a normal plural noun.

üî∏ Segment C: mangoes from

  • ‚úÖ Correct

  • "mangoes" is the correct plural form of mango

  • Preposition ‚Äúfrom‚Äù is used correctly

  • No error here

üî∏ Segment D: the market

  • ‚úÖ Correct

  • Article ‚Äúthe‚Äù + singular noun ‚Äúmarket‚Äù ‚Üí grammatically correct

  • No error here

‚úÖ Final Answer: B. two dozens

question:
The following sentence has been split into four segments. Identify the segment that contains a grammatical error.
One of / the biggest enterprise / in India / is declaring a lockout.

(SSC CGL 2020 T-1 : 20 August Shift 3 (3 to 4 PM))
solution:
Answer: the biggest enterprise

Solution:

  • The phrase ‚ÄúOne of the biggest enterprise in India‚Äù should use the plural noun ‚Äúenterprises‚Äù because ‚Äúone of‚Äù always refers to one item among many.

  • Correct form: ‚ÄúOne of the biggest enterprises in India is declaring a lockout.‚Äù

question:
The following sentence has been split into four segments. Identify the segment that contains a grammatical error.
I do not / like to read / these kind / of novels.

(SSC CGL 2021 T-1 : 21 Apr S2 (12_30 to 1_30 PM))
solution:
Explanation:

üîπ Segment 1: "I do not"

  • ‚úÖ Grammatically correct ‚Äî Subject + auxiliary verb (negative)

üîπ Segment 2: "like to read"

  • ‚úÖ Also correct ‚Äî verb phrase expressing preference

üîπ Segment 3: "these kind" ‚ùå

  • ‚ùå Error: Number agreement

"Kind" is singular, so it should be matched with a singular determiner like "this."

Correct usage:

  • "this kind of novels" (if ‚Äúkind‚Äù is singular ‚Äî but then ‚Äúnovels‚Äù should be singular too: this kind of novel)

  • "these kinds of novels" ‚úÖ (both ‚Äúthese‚Äù and ‚Äúkinds‚Äù are plural, matching ‚Äúnovels‚Äù)

So, the error lies in using "these" (plural) with "kind" (singular).

‚úÖ Corrected sentence:

I do not like to read these kinds of novels.

üìå Final Answer: these kind ‚úÖ

Error Type: Number mismatch
Part of Speech Affected: Determiner + Noun
Rule: Demonstratives like ‚Äúthese‚Äù must agree in number with the noun that follows.

question:
Parts of the following sentence have been given as options. Select the option that contains an error.
The Survey showed that across most tasks that test the ability to apply basic numeracy and reading skills, Primary school boys did best than girls.

(SSC CPO 2024 T-2 (30 April))
option_1: that test the ability to apply
option_2: Primary school boys did best than girls
option_3: The Survey showed that across most tasks
option_4: basic numeracy and reading skills
solution:
Solution:

  • The sentence:
    "The Survey showed that across most tasks that test the ability to apply basic numeracy and reading skills, Primary school boys did best than girls."

  • The error is in: "Primary school boys did best than girls"

  • Explanation:

  • The word "best" is the superlative form of "good" and is used when comparing more than two.

  • When comparing two groups (boys and girls), we should use the comparative form "better" along with "than".

  • So the correct phrase should be: "Primary school boys did better than girls."

  • Why the other options are correct:

  • "that test the ability to apply" ‚Äì grammatically correct.

  • "The Survey showed that across most tasks" ‚Äì correctly structured.

  • "basic numeracy and reading skills" ‚Äì no error in parallel structure.

Corrected sentence:
"The Survey showed that across most tasks that test the ability to apply basic numeracy and reading skills, Primary school boys did better than girls."

question:
The following sentence has been split into four segments. Identify the segment that contains an error.
Stephan, however, contrived / to put away / his departure / for eighteen months.

(SSC MTS 2024 S.21_16-Oct_Shift-1)
solution:
Correct Answer: to put away

Explanation:

  • The phrasal verb "put away" is incorrect in this context.

  • "Put away" means to store or tidy something, which doesn't fit the idea of delaying an action.

  • The correct phrase should be "put off", which means to postpone or delay.

  • Corrected sentence:
    "Stephan, however, contrived to put off his departure for eighteen months."
